title: 107_hr3223
content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. Service connections will be included for facilities in Dulce and surrounding areas. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will enter into a self-determination contract with the Secretary to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems. The Bureau of Reclamation will provide technical assistance and oversight. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the terms "Act" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" for water application in commercial agriculture, "Reclamation" for the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Report" for a specific planning report completed in September 2001. Public Law 106-243 defines key terms such as Reservation, Rural Water Supply Project, State, and Secretary in relation to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. The term "Tribe" refers to the Jicarilla Apache Nation as defined in Public Law 106-243. SEC. 4. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. Pumping and treatment facilities will be located on the Reservation, along with distribution, collection, and treatment facilities to serve the Reservation's needs. The Rural Water Supply Project includes construction, replacement, improvement, and repair of water and wastewater systems on the Reservation, along with appurtenant buildings, access roads, property rights, and other necessary facilities deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The tribal share of the project's cost will be determined based on specific guidelines. The Rural Water Supply Project includes construction, replacement, and improvement of water and wastewater systems on the Reservation. The tribal share of the project's cost covers design and construction of various facilities, which has been fulfilled. The Federal share will cover the remaining costs as identified in the Report, with provisions for operation and maintenance. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will be responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs as outlined in the Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan. The Secretary has the authority to enter contracts and promulgate regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe will develop an OM&R plan for operation and maintenance. A construction manager will be selected to work with the Tribe on the project. The Secretary will enter into a memorandum of agreement with the Tribe for the Rural Water Supply Project, providing oversight, technical assistance, and service within the Reservation boundaries. The Rural Water Supply Project within the Reservation boundaries will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will report to Congress annually on the project's progress. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriation of $45,000,000 for Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction. Funds can only be used after appraisal, feasibility study, and completion of required plan. Secretary must comply with NEPA before construction funds are obligated. The $45,000,000 appropriation for the Rural Water Supply Project can only be used after meeting the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 8 prohibits the use of funds for irrigation purposes in the Rural Water Supply Project. SEC. 9 addresses water rights. SEC. 9 of the Rural Water Supply Project addresses the water rights of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe, which are included in the Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act. These rights are adjudicated under New Mexico State law and provide sufficient water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights. The project's water depletions have been determined to have no significant impact on endangered species.
